review: Benim Adฤฑm Kฤฑrmฤฑzฤฑ = My Name is Red, Orhan Pamuk. My Name Is Red is a 1998 Turkish novel by writer Orhan Pamuk translated into English by Erdaฤ Gรถknar in 2001.. Pamuk would later receive the 2006 Nobel Prize in Literature. The novel, concerning miniaturists in the Ottoman Empire of 1591, established Pamuk's international reputation and contributed to his Nobel Prize. The influences of Joyce, Kafka, Mann, Nabokov and Proust and above all Eco can be seen in Pamuk's work.. ุชุงุฑุฎ ูุฎุณุชู ุฎูุงูุด: ุฑูุฒ ูุดุชู ูุงู ุขฺฏูุณุช ุณุงู 2010ููุงุฏ. ุนููุงู: ูุงู ูู ุณุฑุฎุ ููุณูุฏู ุงูุฑูุงู ูพุงููฺฉุ ูุชุฑุฌู: ุนู ุงููู ุบุฑุจุ ุชูุฑุงูุ ฺุดููุ 1389ุ ุฏุฑ 692ุตุ ฺุงูพ ฺูุงุฑู 1393ุ ููุถูุน ุฏุงุณุชุงููุง ููุณูุฏฺฏุงู ุชุฑฺฉู - ุณุฏู 20ู. ุนููุงู: ูุงู ูู ุณุฑุฎุ ููุณูุฏู: ุงูุฑูุงู ูพุงููฺฉุ ูุชุฑุฌู ุชูููู ุฒุงุฑุฏุดุชุ ุชูุฑุงูุ ูุฑูุงุฑุฏุ 1391ุ ุฏุฑ 594ุตุ ฺุงูพ ุฏูู 1392ุ. ุนููุงู ุฑูุงู ยซูุงู ูู ุณุฑุฎยป ุงุณุชุ ุจุฑฺฏุฑุฏุงู ูุงุฑุณ ุงุฒ ยซุจูู ุขุฏู ูุฑูุฒยปุ ุดุงุฏ ุจุง ุนููุงู ุฏฺฏุฑ ูู ฺุงูพ ุดุฏู ุจุงุดุฏุ ููุฏุงูู.ุ ูุชู ู ุฑูุด ุฑูุงุชุ ุจู ูุฏุฑ ุฒุจุงุณุชุ ฺฉู ุงฺฏุฑ ุจุฎูุงูู ุชฺฉู ุง ุฑุง ุจุฑฺฏุฒููุ ุชุง ุจุฑุง ุฏู ุดูุง ุงูุฌุง ุจฺฉุงุฑูุ ุชุง ุณุจุฒ ุดูุฏุ ุจุงุฏ ููู  ฺฉุชุงุจ ุฑุง ุงุฒ ุงุจุชุฏุง ุชุง ุงูุชูุง ุจููุณูุ ยซุงูุฑูุงูยป ุฏุฑ ุณุงู 2006ููุงุฏุ ุจุฑูุฏู  ุฌุงุฒู ููุจู ุงุฏุจุงุช ุดุฏู ุงูุฏุ ุดุงุฏ ุจุฑุง ููู ฺฉุชุงุจ ุจูุฏูุ ููุด ุงุฒ ุณุฑู ูพุฑุฏุ ุฏูุจุงุฑูุ ุขุบุงุฒ ุจู ุฎูุงูุดุด ฺฉุฑุฏู ุงู.ุ ยซุงูุฑูุงูยป ุฌุง ุฏุฑ ููู ฺฉุชุงุจ ูููุณูุฏ ยซุชุตูุฑ ู ูุชูุ ุฑูฺฏ ู ฺฉูููุ ุจุง ูู ุจุฑุงุฏุฑูุฏยป ยซุงูุฑูุงู ูพุงููฺฉยป ูููุณูุฏ ุจุนุถูุง ูฺฏููุฏ ยซูุงู ูู ุณุฑุฎยปุ ฺฉ ุฑูุงู ุงุฑุงู ุณุชุ ู ูู ููุดู ุงู ุฑุง ฺฉ ุงูุชุฎุงุฑ ุจุฒุฑฺฏุ ู ุชุญุณู ูุฏุงูู.ุ ููุด ู ุฐฺฉุงูุช ููุณูุฏู ฺฉู ูุธุฑ ุงุณุช.ุ. ุชุงุฑุฎ ุจููฺฏุงู ุฑุณุงู 21/05/1399ูุฌุฑ ุฎูุฑุดุฏุ ุง. ุดุฑุจุงู

Kar = Snow, c2002, Orhan Pamuk. Snow, is a novel by Turkish writer Orhan Pamuk. Published in Turkish in 2002, it was translated into English by Maureen Freely and published in 2004.. The story encapsulates many of the political and cultural tensions of modern Turkey and successfully combines humor, social commentary, mysticism, and a deep sympathy with its characters.. Ka is a poet, who returns to Turkey after 12 years of political exile in Germany. He has several motives, first, as a journalist, to investigate a spate of suicides but also in the hope of meeting a woman he used to know.. Heavy snow cuts off the town for about three days during which time Ka is in conversation with a former communist, a secularist, a fascist nationalist, a possible Islamic extremist, Islamic moderates, young Kurds, the military, the Secret Service, the police and in particular, an actor-revolutionary. In the midst of this, love and passion are to be found.. Temporarily closed off from the world, a farcical coup is staged and linked melodramatically to a stage play. The main discussion concerns the interface of secularism and belief but there are references to all of Turkey's twentieth century history.. ุชุงุฑุฎ ูุฎุณุชู ุฎูุงูุด: ุฑูุฒ ูพุงูุฒุฏูู When I visited the museum, there is a section where the author, Orhan Pamuk, talks about the importance of the feelings that books provokes rather than the story itself. We hardly remember the details of the story shortly after reading the books but the emotions that arise submerge into our souls.. From the reviews, I see many non-Turkish readers are struggling to go through book. I respect all the non-Turkish readers who read or who are trying to read this book. I think it will be very hard to get the same taste that a Turkish who were raised in 60s or 70s and lived in Istanbul at some point in his / her life. You will get the story but not the same taste.. Lastly, you will truly enjoy the read, if you are person of obsessive nature.. ---. Masumiyet Mรผzesi'nde yazar Orhan Pamuk'un romanlardaki hikayeden รงok o hikayenin bizde uyandฤฑrdฤฑฤฤฑ duygularฤฑn romanฤฑ deฤerli kฤฑldฤฑฤฤฑndan bahseden bir bรถlรผm vardฤฑ. Romanฤฑ okuduktan kฤฑs bir sรผre sonra hikayenin detaylarฤฑnฤฑ unutuyoruz ama ama bizde uyandฤฑrdฤฑฤฤฑ duygular ruhumunuzun derinliklerine iลliyor.. Yorumlardan yabancฤฑ okurlarฤฑn kitaba devam etmekte zorlandฤฑฤฤฑnฤฑ gรถrรผyorum. Bu kitabฤฑ okumuล ya da okumaya รงalฤฑลan yabancฤฑ okurlarฤฑn 60larda ya da 70lerde Tรผrkiye'de bรผyรผmรผล, hayatฤฑnฤฑn bir dรถneminde dahi Istanbul'da yaลamฤฑล olanlarฤฑn aldฤฑฤฤฑ hazzฤฑ yakalamasฤฑ bence imkansฤฑz.. Son olarak, az da olsa takฤฑntฤฑlฤฑ bir kiลiliฤi olanlarฤฑn romandan daha รงok keyif alacaฤฤฑnฤฑ dรผลรผnรผyorum

Istanbul, Hatฤฑralar ve ลehir = Istanbul: Memories and the City, 2005, Orhan Pamuk. Istanbul: Memories and the City is a largely autobiographical memoir by Orhan Pamuk that is deeply melancholic. It talks about the vast cultural change that has rocked Turkey โ the unending battle between the modern and the receding past.. It is also a eulogy to the lost joint family tradition. Most of all, it is a book about Bosphorus and Istanbul's history with the strait. (ENG BELOW) Orhan Pamuk her seferinde beni ลaลฤฑrtmayฤฑ baลarฤฑyor. Bu sefer de bunu kitabฤฑn baลkarakteri Mevlut ile yaptฤฑ. Onunla hemhal olup ฤฐstanbul sokaklarฤฑnda dolaลmak, 70'lerden bugรผne olan dรถnรผลรผmรผnรผ gรถzlemlemek inanฤฑlmaz bir duyguydu. Mevlut'un ikilemlerini, duygularฤฑnฤฑ iliklerime kadar hissettim. 466 sayfa nasฤฑl hฤฑzla geรงti anlamadฤฑm. En hฤฑzlฤฑ okuduฤum kitaplardan biriydi. Orhan Pamuk'un kavrayฤฑลฤฑna, zekasฤฑna bir kez daha hayran oldum. Mutlaka okuyun.. I really love the mind of Orhan Pamuk. This situation intensifies with the every new book of him that I read. This book is special for me because its center point is ฤฐstanbul. Mevlut (the main character) strolls around the city mostly at night and observes the changing urban landscape. I amazed by looking at the city with the eye of Mevlut who is migrated from the small village of Anatolia. Everyone especially who lives and loves ฤฐstanbul should definitely read this novel. It is like a quick wrap up of my Urban Sociology class in Bogazici University

Yeni Hayat = The New Life, Orhan Pamuk. The protagonist, Osman, first notices the book in the university canteen when a female student, Janan, sets a copy down for a moment on his table. He later buys his own copy at a bookstall and is so thrilled by this novel that he sets off in search of the new life it promises.. Janan introduces Osman to her lover Mehmet who had also read the book and been to the world it describes. Osman, who at this point is enchanted by Janan, witnesses Mehmet gunned down at a bus stop, but the injured man mysteriously disappears and can't be traced at any hospital.. The two embark on surreal bus journeys in search of Mehmet. One of the buses has a road accident which results in fatalities, however, they emerge alive, expropriating wallets and identities of two dead passengers. They continue the journey and encounter Dr. Fine, Mehmet's father.. Spoilers alert. It turns out that he had sent spies to keep watch on his rebellious son and to murder other readers of the book. Janan herself vanishes and Osman goes on more surreal and violent bus journeys. It later appears that a deceased friend of Osman's father, Uncle Rifki, may actually be the author of the book.. ุชุงุฑุฎ ูุฎุณุชู ุฎูุงูุด: ุฑูุฒ ุดุงูุฒุฏูู ูุงู ููุงูุจุฑ ุณุงู Siddharta, the son of a brahmin, becomes a monk among the Samanas, then a pilgrim, a merchant, a traveler, a ferryman. Obeying his inner voice, he wants to find his personal truth and make sense out of these different situations and conditions in life.. RELATED STORIES :. Lร-Bas. = Down There / The Damned. Le Loup des steppes. = Steppenwolf. Une vie. The Book of Disquiet: The Complete Edition. Immortelle randonnรฉe : Compostelle malgrรฉ moi. Le mythe de Sisyphe. = The Myth of Sisyphus. La Possibilitรฉ d'une รฎle. = The Possibility of an Island. Choir :. Om - The Moody Blues. ----------. Le rรฉcit initiatique de Siddharta, fils de brahmane respectueux des traditions qui ne se satisfait pas de la vie contemplative et docte et laisse sa voix intรฉrieure le guider dans la recherche de sa vรฉritรฉ personnelle.. Il rencontre les moines Samanas, qui lui enseignent la mortification, le mรฉpris du corps et l'impitoyable dรฉtachement de soi-mรชme, puis Gotama et l'univers d'adoration, de messianisme, d'attente anxieuse du salut par un sauveur. Il rompt avec les maรฎtres et cherche sa voie en lui-mรชme. Il demande au passeur de lui faire traverser le fleuve. C'est la premiรจre rupture.. Il va au village, oรน il devient marchand et apprend la science de l'amour auprรจs de Kamala. Pour l'รฉtranger en terre รฉtrangรจre, c'est l'apprentissage de l'exil hors du connu, hors de lui-mรชme. Siddharta vit en homme divisรฉ, absent aux autres et ร lui-mรชme. Il aborde la vie en homme supรฉrieur, arrogant, agrippant les biens, craignant la mort.. Aprรจs des annรฉes, il quitte la ville et laisse ses biens derriรจre lui, plein de dรฉgoรปt. Il cherche une rupture totale avec ses vies prรฉcรฉdentes. Habitรฉ par des pensรฉes de suicide, il vit une รฉpiphanie devant le fleuve, l'esprit rayonnant de la syllabe "Om". C'est une mort symbolique. Il est rรฉgรฉnรฉrรฉ par l'affection qu'il porte au passeur Vasudeva. Les deux hommes s'entretiennent, il apprend de lui et du fleuve que le monde est une folie mue par l'รฉternel retour. Le hรฉros sort de lui-mรชme. Le temps n'existe plus pour lui. Il apprend la nรฉcessitรฉ pour chacun de passer par Samsara, l'impermanence, pour connaรฎtre sa voie.. INDEX :. - Le fils du brahmane. - Chez les Samanas. - Gotama. - Le rรฉveil. - Kamala. - Parmi les hommes. - Sansara. - Au bord du fleuve. - Le passeur. - Son fils. - Om. - Govinda. [Tiแบฟng Viแปt bรชn dฦฐแปi]. First of all, what I need to say is that what the book discusses is totally not what Gotama the Buddha taught. As the one admiring Buddhism, I did expect Hesse could provide me his insightful understanding of what the Buddha said, as supplement to what I have learnt. Yet, absolutely tout-ร-fait I get disappointed, Hesse seems to not intend to do what I expected. I cannot say if he really understood what the Buddha have done during his life of teaching when he said in this book that Govinda the Buddhaโs fellow is a searcher. The Buddhaโs fellows in my point of view are not searchers, they are ones practicing the Path provided by the Buddha.. Moreover, as a Buddhist, one should accept that living is suffering indeed and monk, who should comprehend this, blissfully lives not because he/she is salvaged but they do amor fati โ comprehend their fate. Hence, all lyrics from Govinda could be considered as Buddist ignorance.. One said that "You can learn a great deal about German Protestantism from reading Siddhartha, but almost nothing about Buddhism". Unfortunately, I donโt understand anything about Protestantism to judge this, but you can believe that you cannot learn anything about Buddhism from this book.. ***. review: ****Primera lectura del aรฑo del club Pickwick:. www.instagram.com/clubpickwick/. )****. Esta es una lectura que necesito dejar reposar.. El lobo estepario es una novela cargada hasta tal punto de simbolismos, metรกforas y. reflexiones existencialistas. que creo que pide un tiempo para ser digerida.. Dicho esto, me ha gustado, la lectura para mi ha sido un poco de montaรฑa rusa, con una parte inicial que me encantรณ, una central que me resultรณ densa y un desenlace completamente de locura (nunca mejor dicho).. Lo mรกs interesante de todo para mi es ese fuerte componente antibelicista y cรณmo Hesse transmite tan bien su incapacidad para integrarse en la sociedad. No se le puede negar ademรกs, lo original y moderno que debiรณ resultar para el momento de su publicaciรณn.. Aรบn asรญ a veces el mensaje me resultaba demasiado obvio y otros incomprensible.... lo dicho, es una obra hecha para dejar al lector reflexionando, y eso Hesse lo logra completamente.

A primeira leitura de 2021 jรก comeรงou muito marcante para mim. Como comentei com vocรชs, fazia algum tempo que nรฃo me identificava tanto com um livro. Jรก era um grande fรฃ de Hesse depois de ter lido โSidartaโ e โKnulpโ e, depois de โO lobo da estepeโ, talvez possa falar que o autor estรก no meu top 10 de escritores favoritos.. Nessa obra, Hesse apresenta ao leitor a histรณria de Harry Haller, um homem na faixa dos 50 anos que vive crises existenciais, e รฉ por meio dos diรกlogos internos do protagonista que o autor, influenciado pela psicanรกlise, traz reflexรตes interessantรญssimas sobre a condiรงรฃo humana.. No comeรงo da narrativa, nos deparamos com um Harry cansado da vida e que, constantemente, รฉ acometido por pensamentos suicidas. Esse estado psicolรณgico do personagem deixa o comeรงo da leitura atรฉ mesmo mais parada_ talvez tenha sido algo intencional, a fim de refletir a melancolia de Harry_, mas um acontecimento pouco inusitado em sua vida coloca o personagem de frente com โO tratado do lobo da estepeโ e com novas amizades que trarรฃo uma vontade de viver a Harry. ร a partir desse momento que a narrativa se desenrola de forma extraordinรกria!. Hรก, tambรฉm, uma crรญtica constante ร hipocrisia que recai muitas vezes sobre a classe burguesa. Isso porque o protagonista tece diversos comentรกrios contra a burguesia, esquecendo, por sua vez, que ele mesmo se enquadra como uma luva nessa faixa social.. Achei interessante que, no posfรกcio da obra, o autor avisa que leitores mais prรณximos da meia idade tendem a se identificar ainda mais com os pensamentos do personagem. "ยกAh, es difรญcil encontrar esa huella de Dios en medio de esta vida que llevamos, en medio de este siglo tan contentadizo, tan burguรฉs, tan falto de espiritualidad, a la vista de estas arquitecturas, de estos negocios, de esta polรญtica, de estos hombres!. Cรณmo no habรญa de ser yo un lobo estepario y un pobre anacoreta en medio de un mundo, ninguno de cuyos fines comparto, ninguno de cuyos placeres me llama la atenciรณn?". Quรฉ bien que escribe Hermann Hesse.... Hay algo en los escritores alemanes que supera a muchos de otros paรญses. Son dueรฑos de una narrativa bella, contundente... casi perfecta.. Me sucede lo mismo cuando leo al padre de la literatura alemana, Goethe, o al enorme y maravilloso Thomas Mann, (cuyo estilo me recuerda mucho a Hesse), a Schiller o E.T.A. Hoffmann. Dueรฑos de una prosa incomparable, saben cรณmo atraer al lector para no dejarlo escapar.. Algo similar sucede con los escritores franceses que los distingue del resto, pero debo decir que Alemania prevalece sobre el resto. Hasta Franz Kafka siendo checo decidiรณ escribir en alemรกn y Jorge Luis Borges decidiรณ aprender alemรกn como autodidacta para leer a Goethe en su idioma original.. En este libro, Herman Hesse nos sumerge en el mundo especial de su lobo estepario, Harry Haller que no casualmente posee las mismas iniciales, ya que la novela estรก impregnada de sus propias experiencias, es notablemente biogrรกfica y refleja sus problemas y su lucha contra la depresiรณn y el suicidio.. El libro no estรก dividido por capรญtulos sino que cuenta con partes bien diferenciadas.. Una introducciรณn, en la que un desconocido narrador nos dan las nociones bรกsicas introductorias acerca de este personaje tan peculiar llamado Harry Haller, quien se autodenomina un "lobo estepario", a quien conociรณ ya mayor viviendo en la pensiรณn de su tรญa.. Luego las anotaciones de Harry Haller conocidas como "Sรณlo para locos" en las que encontramos unas primeras impresiones y experiencias vividas y en la que nos adentraremos dentro de su propia pqsiquis, conoceremos cรณmo piensa este solitario cinquentรณn que decidiรณ abrazar su vida al peregrinaje urbano y la soledad.. Despuรฉs, nos encontramos con un descriptivo apartado llamado el "Tractat del lobo estepario (no para cualquiera)" en el que el autor ahonda nuevamente dentro de la personalidad de Haller, haciendo hincapiรฉ tanto en su visiรณn de la burguesรญa no como crรญtica sino como diferenciaciรณn del estilo de vida del personajes y de otras cuestiones ligadas especialmente al suicidio y a la dualidad que convive dentro de Haller, dualidad en la que muchos encontrarรกn rastros de "bipolaridad" con una carga de "crisis existencial".. Esa dualidad estรก orientada a la cuestiรณn fรกustica planteada por Goethe en su novela "Fausto" y que en Harry Haller tiene ademรกs la particularidad de romperse como un espejo en muchos fragmentos mรกs que lo llevan a replantearse su vida en todas sus etapas pasadas, la presente e incluso el futuro.. La disertaciรณn del autor sobre Haller va mucho mรกs allรก. Es mucho mรกs profunda y encara puntualmente en la introspecciรณn psicolรณgica del personaje preparando al lector a lo que va a venir: la narraciรณn propiamente dicha de las vivencias de Haller y su enfrentamiento a los escollos de la vida y las posibles consecuencia que le traigan sus acciones.. El vacรญo existencial que sufre a principios de la novela y el tormento del suicidio le atraen casi de la misma forma que a otro personaje conflictuado: el de Kirilov en la novela "Los demonios" de Fiรณdor Dostoievski, con la diferencia de que Haller no sucumbe sino que lucha por salir del pozo y lo logra desde el momento en el que conoce a otros personajes clave de la novela como lo serรกn Hermine, Marรญa y Pablo.. Las รกcidas conclusiones de hombre del subsuelo que lo aquejan comienzan a transformarse en la esperanza de que se puede vivir sin tanto complejo y de esta manera, Haller comienza a experimentar ciertos placeres solamente reservados a esa burguesรญa que tanto critica.. Tanto deambular hace que se suceda el (no tan) fortuito encuentro con Hermine (o Armanda segรบn la traducciรณn que uno lea) en el bar "El รกguila negra" y a partir de este evento todo cambiarรก incluso para bien.. Hermine le darรก la posibilidad de acercarse a otras experiencias placenteras, especialmente la del baile, algo impensado tanto para Harry como para nosotros los lectores, por lo que venรญamos leyendo sobre รฉl.. Armanda y el baile (cuando no, una mujer para "despertarnos" y ponernos en la buena senda) le aportarรกn luz a su vida y a partir de que conoce a otra hermosa mujer llamada Marรญa ahondarรก en los placeres de la sensualidad y el sexo, saliendo de ese letargo que lo aprisionaba.. Adentrรกndonos en el รบltimo tercio de la novela, Harry concurrirรก a un baile de mรกscaras y de buenas a primeras, gracias a su amigo, el saxofonista Pablo, durante ese evento en el que el autor detalla con lo mejor de la carnavalizaciรณn rabelesiana, se introducirรก en una especie de noche de Walpurgis en la que Hesse homenajea nuevamente al "Fausto" de Goethe tal como lo hiciera Mijaรญl Bulgรกkov en ese capรญtulo de "El maestro y Margarita" en el que Voland invita a Margarita disfrutar su propia noche de gala.. Y de ahรญ y casualmente como por arte de magia, Pablo le darรก la posibilidad de conocer a su "Teatro mรกgico -sรณlo para locos-" en donde la entrada "solo cuesta la razรณn" y no es para cualquiera.. Aquรญ ingresaremos, a la parte mรกs surrealista de la novela, una especie de sucursal del paรญs de las maravillas de Alicia, ya que en este teatro en forma de herradura, Harry se encontrarรก con muchas puertas en un extremo y espejos en el otro y cada una de ellas lo llevarรก a una experiencia que metafรณricamente hablando, lo colocarรกn en distintas etapas de su vida para experimentarlas nuevamente como si fuera un autรฉntico sueรฑo delirante y kafkiano, absurdo y onรญrico. Asรญ es: un autรฉntico ensamble kafkiano.. Esta es la parte mรกs entretenida y alucinada del libro. Ya hace mucho que Harry no es ese lobo huraรฑo y recalcitrante sino un hombre entregado a las pasiones, delirios y desenfrenos del espรญritu.. El final es completamente distinto a lo que leรญmos al principio, pero tiene mucho que ver tanto con Harry Haller como con Herman Hesse.. Habรญa leรญdo este libro hace siete aรฑos y debo reconocer que disfrutรฉ muchรญsimo de esta novela "no tan sรณlo para locos" que me permitiรณ reafirmar la grandeza de este gran escritor que se llamรณ Hermann Hesse.

4.5 stars. Ich besuchte vor vielen Jahren Hesses Grab in Montagnola, las einen Teil seiner Tessiner Geschichten und ein paar Gedichte โ doch bis jetzt habe ich nie einen Roman von ihm gelesen. Und das ist wahrscheinlich gut so. Denn hรคtte ich Hesses โDer Steppenwolfโ in meinen Zwanzigern gelesen, mein Urteil รผber dieses Buch wรคre wohl um einiges schlechter ausgefallen. Die Zeitlosigkeit dieser Erzรคhlung ermรถglicht es, mich rund 90 Jahre spรคter als Frau mittleren Alters in die Gefรผhlswelt des Harry Hallers einzuleben. Wieso jedoch hatte das Buch eine so grosse Resonanz unter der (vor allem amerikanischen) Jugendbewegungen der 1960-er Jahre?. Das Buch schildert auf eindrรผckliche, wenn auch zuweilen bedrรผckende Weise Harry Hallers Zerrissenheit zwischen seiner Bรผrgerlichkeit, die er verachtet,. โdiese fette gedeihliche Zucht des Mittelmรคssigen, Normalen, Durchschnittlichenโ. , nach deren Ordnung und Reinlichkeit er sich jedoch irgendwie sehnt. โEin Leben voll Anstand und Gesundheit, mit Frรผhaufstehen, Pflichterfรผllung, gemรคssigt heiteren Familienfesten, sonntรคglichem Kirchgang und frรผhem Schlafengehenโ. und seiner wilden Natur - dem Steppenwolf - der frei und unabhรคngig leben will und sich um Konventionen schert. Er flรผchtet sich in seine Intellektualitรคt, die ihn von der Masse abheben soll, verehrt Mozart sowie Goethe und verabscheut Jazzmusik. Er liest die aktuellen Tageszeitungen, deren Inhalt ihn zutiefst bedrรผckt (und hier flechtet Hesse in weiser Vorahnung seine Befรผrchtungen รผber den aufflammenden deutschen Nationalsozialismus ein):. โZwei Drittel von meinen Landsleuten lesen diese Art von Zeitungen, lesen jeden Morgen und Abend diese Tรถne, werden jeden Tag bearbeitet, ermahnt, verhetzt, unzufrieden und bรถse gemacht, und das Ziel und Ende von dem allen ist wieder der Krieg, ist der nรคchste, kommende Krieg, der wohl noch scheusslicher sein wird, als dieser er war.โ. Die Charakterstudie รผber Harry Haller ist brilliant geschrieben, aber schwer zu verdauen. Hier hรคtte ich als Zwanzigjรคhrige wahrscheinlich mit Lesen aufgegeben, weil mich Harrys Niedergeschlagenheit zu sehr mit hinuntergezogen hรคtte. Heute lese ich jedoch tapfer weiter und werde bald belohnt: Harry Haller trifft diejenigen Protagonisten des Buches, die ihn auf seinem Weg der Selbstfindung begleiten und ihn erziehen: die androgyne Hermine, der bisexuelle Jazzsaxophonist Pablo und die sinnliche Maria. Hallers Leben รคndert sich ab hier schlagartig und auch das Buch wird dementsprechend farbiger, interessanter und humorvoller. Denn Humor ist der Schlรผssel und die Antwort auf Harrys Leiden. Hermine, Pablo und Maria sind faszinierende symbolische Charaktere, und sie verkรถrpern den Individualismus und Nonkonformismus nach dem sich ein Teil Harrys sehnt. Wer sich fรผr die Psychologie von C.G. Jung interessiert, sollte in diesen Charakteren einige Archetypen von C.G. Jung wiederfinden.. Im letzten Teil des Buches besucht Harry unter Drogeneinfluss das โMagische Theaterโ dessen Besitzer Pablo ist. Und hier geht die Post erst richtig ab. Harry รถffnet verschiedene Tรผren, die zu verschiedenen Welten fรผhren und denen er sich stellen muss. Ich will nicht zu viel verraten, ausser dass es eine kรถstliche Begegnung mit Mozart und einem Radioapparat gibt.. Ist das Buch ein Aufruf zu freiem Sex und Drogenkonsum wie es die Blumenkinder der 60er so gerne propagierten? Ich glaube nicht wirklich. Aber wenn man das Leben nicht mehr so todernst nimmt, ist der Zugang zur eigenen Sexualitรคt und vielleicht der Umgang mit gewissen Substanzen unverkrampfter. Und gemรคss Hermine soll man ja auch Spass an der Mode haben.. โIch lernte vor allem, dass diese kleine Spielzeuge, Mode- und Luxussachen nicht bloss Tand und Kitsch sind und eine Erfindung geldgieriger Fabrikanten und Hรคndler, sondern berechtigt, schรถn, mannigfaltig, eine kleine oder vielmehr grosse Welt von Dingen, welche alle den einzigen Zweck haben, der Liebe zu dienen, die Sinne zu verfeinern, die tote Umwelt zu beleben und zauberhaft mit neuen Liebesorganen zu begaben, vom Puder und Parfรผm bis zum Tanzschuh, vom Fingerring bis zur Zigarettendose, von der Gรผrtelschnalle bis zur Handtascheโ. . Ich kann also Mozart und Goethe verehren und trotzdem die VOGUE lesen!. Dieses Buch ist zeitlos und auch heute brandaktuell. Ich denke, es war seiner Zeit voraus bezรผglich gesellschaftlicher Aspekte (Individualismus, Sexualitรคt,) aber es ist auch von weiser Vorahnung geprรคgt in Anbetracht des damals drohenden, deutschen Nationalsozialismus und technischer Errungenschaften. Mit dem Ende des Buches ist Harrys Selbstfindung nicht etwa abgeschlossen, sondern sie hat erst richtig begonnen. Aber er hat begriffen, was es dazu braucht, er hat den Schlรผssel dazu in der Hand: den Humor und das Lachen. Das Verbinden von Intellektualitรคt mit Spass, Lachen, moderner Musik und Mode und das รberwinden des Kleinbรผrgerlichen, mag wohl bei den Jugendlichen der 60er Jahre ein solches grosses Echo ausgelรถst haben.. Zitate aus Herman Hesses โDer Steppenwolfโ, die ich mochte:. โIn der Welt zu leben, als sei es nicht die Welt, das Gesetz zu achten und doch รผber ihm zu stehen, zu besitzen, โals besรคsse man nichtโ, zu verzichten, als sei es kein Verzicht โ alle diese beliebten und oft formulierten Forderungen einer hohen Lebensweisheit ist einzig der Humor zu verwirklichen fรคhig.โ. โNun, aller hรถhere Humor fรคngt damit an, dass man die eigene Person nicht mehr ernst nimmt.โ. โLernen Sie ernst nehmen, was des Ernstnehmens wert ist, und lachen รผber das andere!โ

Wie viele andere Leser habe ich den STEPPENWOLF als Teenager gelesen und war damals begeistert. Hermann Hesse, verachtet von meiner Deutschlehrerin, zรคhlte zu meinen liebsten Schriftstellern. Je grรถรer die Abneigung der alten Dame war, desto stรคrker wurde meine Anhรคngerschaft. Deutsch war mein liebstes Fach. Sie wollte mich festnageln auf die Klassiker des 19. Jahrhunderts. Ich wollte Rebellion, wurde zornig, zog mich zurรผck und liebte es, meinen Bรถll, Hesse und Lenz als Einzelgรคnger zu lesen. Ich wollte ein Steppenwolf sein und fรผhlte mich ganz so wie Harry Haller. Wรผtend auf das Bรผrgertum, die Spieรigkeit, die Menschen, die mich nicht so sein lassen wollten, wie ich war. Doch irgendwann war die Schulzeit vorbei, Hesse komplett gelesen und der Literaturgeschmack ging in eine andere Richtung.. Das war vor รผber 30 Jahren. Heute bin ich so alt wie Hesse als er das Buch schrieb und damit auch so alt wie Harry Haller, der Steppenwolf. Genau die richtige Zeit, um das Buch nochmal zu lesen. Auf den ersten Seiten kam mir das alte Gefรผhl an Kampfgeist wieder hoch, doch schnell รคnderte sich mein Blick auf den Steppenwolf. Mir fielen plรถtzlich Passagen auf, die ich offensichtlich in meinem jugendlichen Leichtsinn รผbergangen hatte. Haller rebellierte zwar, doch liebte er auch die saubere Idylle seiner Vermieterin. Selbst hier im Anfang merkt man, dass zwei Herzen in Haller schlagen. Doch es sind nicht nur zwei Rollen, die der Mensch einnimmt, wir fรผhlen uns in vielen Punkten hin und hergerissen. Stรคndig ziehen wir uns neue Rollen รผber und so macht sich der Hesse im Traktat รผber Haller lustig, wenn dieser sich selbst auf der Frage, ob er Mensch oder Wolf ist, reduziert. Interessant, wie man im Alter das Buch mit anderen Augen liest, aber auch verstรคndlich, denn als junger Mensch muss man noch nicht in so viele Rollen schlรผpfen.. Haller lernt im Verlauf der Geschichte Hermine kennen, die ihm das Lachen lehrt, lรคsst sich mit Maria verkuppeln, die ihn das Lieben lernt. Er lernt zu tanzen, Spaร zu haben, gesellig zu sein. Humor als Medizin. Auch das war mir als junger Leser fremd, denn trotz aller Rebellion, wusste ich schon, wie man lacht und sich freut. Warum sollte das so schwer sein? Ich habe das Buch doch mit einem รคuรerst eingeschrรคnkten Blickwinkel gelesen. Dank der eigenen Lebenskrisen kann ich Haller erst jetzt richtig verstehen.. Ich wurde wรคhrend des Lesens gefragt, ob man den STEPPENWOLF im Alter nochmal lesen sollte, denn es wรคre doch eigentlich ein Buch fรผr die Jugend. Oder fรผr die drogenstimulierte Hippiebewegung. Aber Steppenwolf bedeutet nicht bekifft auf dem Highway entlangzufahren und Born to be wild zu hรถren. Das Buch ist unbedingt lesenswert, wenn man die Mitte des Lebens erreicht hat. Der Steppenwolf steckt zwar zu Beginn seines Buchs in einer Krise, steht kurz vor dem Selbstmord, aber Hesse lรคsst ihn einen Weg der Heilung finden. Wie bei so vielen spirituellen Bรผchern Hesses. Manche Kritiker mรถgen das als schwรผlstig bezeichnen oder als Psychologie auf einfachen Niveau. Mich sprechen seine Bilder auch jetzt noch beim Wiederlesen an und ich verstehe das Buch erst heute richtig, oder vielmehr besser. Denn die abschlieรenden Traum- und Drogensequenzen im Magischen Theater lassen viel Spielraum fรผr Interpretationen. Und Hesse hat beklagt, dass dieses Buch gerade von den begeisterten Anhรคnger oft missverstanden wurde. Insofern bin ich vielleicht auch auf dem Holzweg, aber letztlich steht es ja jedem Leser frei, dass in einem Buch herauszulesen, was er empfindet. Ich bleibe bei 5 Sternen und einer Ablage im Favoritenordner.

Un libro complejo que es complicado de digerir. La forma de escribir del autor me gusta y encontrรฉ algunos elementos en comรบn con Demian otra novela del autor que me encantรณ y por eso esperaba un poco mรกs del lobo estepario, y aunque lo tuvo, porque no puedo negarlo, no resultรณ ser de mi agrado.. Los libros en general que te dejan con una sensaciรณn de no haber comprendido por completo lo que trataron de decir son una apuesta, por un lado me gusta que te inciten a investigar y a saber un poco mรกs y te invitan a una relfexiรณn mรกs profunda de la historia, pero por el otro creo que me dejan una idea imprecisa que me hace sentirme insatisfecha.. Al revisar y compartir opiniones encontrรฉ que sรญ comprendรญ la trama y escencia, pero no la disfrutรฉ, es decir no fue un mal libro y Hermann me parece un autor muy bueno, pero en este caso la historia del Lobo se me hizo un poco alocada al final, me gustรณ que tocara ciertas oposiciones, concepto que me encanta. Pero todo el proceso de autoconocimiento de Harry se fue por el agujero de Alicia en el paรญs de las maravillas, bastante ingenioso, pero ese final no funcionรณ para nada para mรญ.

Es una novela compleja, autobiogrรกfica, la cual nos plantea la dualidad del ser humano, racional y animal (amor , odio). Descrita metafรณricamente. El problema existencial que refleja Harry Haller (protagonista), los altibajos que presenta en su vida diaria y sus fuertes depresiones que lo llevan a pensar en el suicidio, es perturbadora.. "El teatro mรกgico" representa la vida misma, junto con personajes muy peculiares, que se presentan como espejos del ser interior (el yo) y a la que se aรฑade una crรญtica fuerte hacia la sociedad de esa รฉpoca, situada durante la guerra.. Debo decir que no fue de mis lecturas favoritas, pero si tiene mucho tema para analizar.

Sesso, droga e โฆ.foxtrott. [Rilettura]. Pubblicato nel 1927, โIl lupo della steppaโ รจ un romanzo- matrioska:. introdotto da un supposto curatore racconta la storia dellโintellettuale Herry Haller attraverso un manoscritto di memorie ritrovate.. Allโinterno del manoscritto, poi, si trova la dissertazione dal titolo โIl lupo della steppaโ che spiega il significato di questa denominazione.. Il disagio di non sentirsi in sintonia con la propria epoca porta ad un isolamento che se inizialmente รจ motivo di fierezza si rivela poi un boccone a amaro.. Lโincontro con lโandrogino Erminia condurrร Haller ad affrontare un percorso di conoscenza del sรฉ. Un uomo che รจ sempre vissuto tra i libri e si รจ formato solo su abilitร intellettuali รจ spinto a misurarsi con il mondo materiale per scoprire che la vita non รจ un poema epico ma un susseguirsi di piccoli atti semplici.. Erminia sarร la guida attraverso cui (ri)scoprire i piaceri: il ballo e la mondanitร borghese dapprima disprezzata assumono un nuovo aspetto; i piaceri della carne sembrano non avere limiti ed un aiutino per entrare dentro se stessi.. Droga: tanta e pesante, direi, visto le allucinazioni che compongono lโultima parte del romanzo.. Cosa non si fa per arrivare a capire il valore di una risata!!!. Un romanzo fatto di ambiguitร che non sono duplici ma molteplici come la serie di โioโ che ognuno contiene.. Chissร se Hesse aveva letto Pirandello? D'altra parte โUno ,nessuno e centomilaโ era stato pubblicato giusto lโanno prima..... โ Tutta la vita รจ cosรฌ, caro mio, e bisogna prenderla com'รจ; e chi non รจ asino ci ride. La gente come lei non ha il diritto di criticare la radio o la vita. Impari prima ad ascoltare! Impari a prendere sul serio quel che merita di essere preso sul serio e a ridere del rimanente!โ

3.5. Este libro me ha resultado una lectura intensa, muy diferente de cualquier otra cosa que haya leรญdo nunca. Algunas de las reflexiones que se hacen en el mismo, me han resultado increรญbles.. En muchos momentos, me he sentido identificada con el protagonista, y en otros muchos, no tenรญa ni idea de lo que estaba leyendo, ni a donde me iba a llevar.. Tengo la sensaciรณn de que me he dejado muchas cosas por el camino, y que va a ser un libro que me va a dar mucho que pensar en el futuro.

Muy probablemente, la obra maestra de su autor y una de las novelas filosรณficas mรกs importantes del siglo veinte, donde se muestra la incapacidad que sufrieron algunos ciudadanos europeos para adaptarse a la gran cantidad de cambios acaecidos en occidente (casi todos ellos de carรกcter tecnolรณgico, social y econรณmico) durante los llamados "felices aรฑos veinte", empezando por la poca cabida que tenรญa la espiritualidad en un mundo que empezaba a ser gobernado por el consumismo, el hedonismo y la superficialidad y finalizando en aspectos como el fin de la identidad del individuo, que se veรญa (y se ve) obligado a volverse camaleรณnico, para asumir la gran cantidad de cambios que ocurren en tiempos muy breves a su alrededor y donde su personalidad queda capada para adoptar una actitud pragmรกtica que sirva a los intereses de empresas, polรญticos y demรกs entidades de gran poder.. Ese lobo estepario al que hace referencia al tรญtulo no es sino la represiรณn que sufrimos un alto porcentaje de la poblaciรณn al vernos obligados a vivir en entornos que no nos llenan ni nos satisfacen plenamente teniendo que aislarnos del resto en ciertos momentos y maneras para conseguir un amago de satisfacciรณn plena.. Como punto negativo he de mencionar la (a dรญa de hoy) visiรณn un tanto ingenua de su personaje principal sobre el mundo que le rodea, con una mentalidad y una madurez que a veces se torna casi infantil, o que al menos da la impresiรณn de ser propia de una persona mucho mรกs joven que ese cincuentรณn que es Harry Haller. En este sentido, si bien es cierto que mantiene vigente algunos aspectos que se muestran de rabiosa actualidad, otros se tornan algo desfasados, o al menos, en cierta medida, modificados, actualizados.

ยซPor otra parte, a todos los suicidas les es familiar la lucha con la tentaciรณn del suicidio. Todos saben muy bien, en alguno de los rincones de su alma, que el suicidio es, en efecto, una salida, pero muy vergonzante e ilegal, que en el fondo es mรกs noble y mรกs bello dejarse vencer y sucumbir por la vida misma y por la propia mano.ยป Del Tractat del Lobo Estepario.. Este libro es sublime. Y queda claro que Harry Haller fuma mierda de la buena.

Foi uma sensaรงรฃo estranha, e era algo que jรก tinha sentido, e ainda recordo, de โSiddharthaโ, tanto que nessa altura, lembro-me de ter questionado se aquilo nรฃo teria sido um relato encontrado algures pelo autor, dada a simplicidade emanada das descriรงรตes de questรตes que tinha, e tenho, como complexas, oriundas de um conjunto de escritos budistas.. Quase terminava a leitura por causa desta introduรงรฃo, mas Hesse redime-se quando abre o discurso, e nos diz que somos feito nรฃo de duas, mas de muitas mais almas, ou facetas, nรฃo dez nem cem, mas mil, as que forem necessรกrias: โtentar explicar um indivรญduo tรฃo diferenciado como Harry segundo uma ingรฉnua divisรฃo em lobo e ser humano consiste numa tentativa desesperadamente infantil. Hesse vai entรฃo usar esta sua abordagem pela multiplicidade dos Eus para propor aos leitores a redenรงรฃo ou cura do mal estar da alienaรงรฃo, ainda que tudo isto nรฃo passe de uma racionalizaรงรฃo desenvolvida quase como um processo de auto-ajuda: โรquele que vivenciou a fragmentaรงรฃo do seu eu demonstramos que em qualquer altura pode voltar a combinar os pedaรงos segundo a ordem que desejar, obtendo assim uma infinita variedade de possibilidades no jogo da vida. Da mesma forma que um escritor cria um drama a partir de uma mancheia de personagens, tambรฉm nรณs, com recurso รs peรงas do nosso ยซeuยป decomposto, construรญmos sempre novos grupos, com novos jogos e expectativas, com eternamente novas situaรงรตes. โ. review: ยซSympathy for the Devilยป. His name is God. Not Lucifer,not Satan,but God!!!. Satan is God in a bad mood. God in a bad mood lays our souls to waste.. ยซAs heads is tales. Just call me LUCIFER. cop is to criminal as God is to Luciferยป.. God in a good mood plays games with us.. ยซWhatโs confusing you is just THE NATURE OF MY GAMEยป. ยซThis song has a direct tie to the book, "the Master and the Margarita", is about all the history & tragedies with points throughout time. The man he is describing is the devil.The devil is asking for sympathy because he claims the reason he is not to blame is because the devil does not make you do anything. He simply sets the stage, which is the nature of his game. Look up those points in time. You should know most of them from historyยป. Someone said.. His name --> the devil --> humanity.. A masterful song for a masterpiece.... ยซPlease allow me to introduce myself. I'm a man of wealth and taste. I've been around for a long, long year. Stole many a man's soul to waste. [[[[[[[And I was 'round when Jesus Christ. Had his moment of doubt and pain. Made damn sure that Pilate. Washed his hands and sealed his fate]]]]]]]]]. Pleased to meet you. Hope you guess my name. But what's puzzling you. Is the nature of my game. [{I stuck around St. Petersburg. When I saw it was a time for a change. Killed the czar and his ministers. Anastasia screamed in vain}]. I rode a tank. Held a general's rank. When the blitzkrieg raged. And the bodies stank. Pleased to meet you. Hope you guess my name. Ah, what's puzzling you. Is the nature of my game. I watched with glee. While your kings and queens. Fought for ten decades. For the gods they made. Let me please introduce myself. I'm a man of wealth and taste. And I laid traps for troubadours. Who get killed before they reached Bombay. Pleased to meet you. Hope you guessed my name. (Who who). But what's puzzling you. Is the nature of my game, get down, baby. Pleased to meet you. Hope you guessed my name. But what's confusing you. Is just the nature of my game. [{JUST AS EVERY COP IS A CRIMINAL. AND ALL THE SINNERS SAINTS. AS HEADS IS TAILS. JUST CALL ME LUCIFER}]. [{Cause I'm in need of some restraint. So if you meet me. Have some courtesy. Have some sympathy, and some taste}]. Use all your well-learned politesse. Or I'll lay your soul to waste. Pleased to meet you. Hope you guessed my name. But what's puzzling you. IS THE NATURE OF MY GAME mean it, get down. Tell me baby, what's my name. Tell me honey, can you guess my name. Tell me baby, what's my name. 959.	โญโโDie Leiden des jungen Werthersโญโญ = Les souffrances du jeune Wertherโฌ = The Sorrows of Young Werther, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. A Autobiographical novel by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, first published in 1774.. Most of The Sorrows of Young Werther, a story about unrequited love, is presented as a collection of letters written by Werther, a young artist of a sensitive and passionate temperament, to his friend Wilhelm.. These give an intimate account of his stay in the fictional village of Wahlheim (based on Garbenheim, near Wetzlar), whose peasants have enchanted him with their simple ways.. Spoiler Alert. There he meets Charlotte, a beautiful young girl who takes care of her siblings after the death of their mother. Werther falls in love with Charlotte despite knowing beforehand that she is engaged to a man named Albert, eleven years her senior.. Despite the pain it causes him, Werther spends the next few months cultivating a close friendship with them both. His sorrow eventually becomes so unsupportable that he is forced to leave Wahlheim for Weimar, where he makes the acquaintance of Frรคulein von B. He suffers great embarrassment when he forgetfully visits a friend and unexpectedly has to face there the weekly gathering of the entire aristocratic set.. He is not tolerated and asked to leave since he is not a nobleman. He then returns to Wahlheim, where he suffers still more than before, partly because Charlotte and Albert are now married. Every day becomes a torturing reminder that Charlotte will never be able to requite his love.. She, out of pity for her friend and respect for her husband, decides that Werther must not visit her so frequently. He visits her one final time, and they are both overcome with emotion after he recites to her a passage of his own translation of Ossian.. Even before that incident, Werther had hinted at the idea that one member of the love triangle โ Charlotte, Albert or Werther himself โ had to die to resolve the situation. Unable to hurt anyone else or seriously consider murder, Werther sees no other choice but to take his own life.. After composing a farewell letter to be found after his death, he writes to Albert asking for his two pistols, on the pretext that he is going "on a journey".. Charlotte receives the request with great emotion and sends the pistols. Werther then shoots himself in the head, but does not die until twelve hours later. He is buried between two lime trees that he had mentioned frequently in his letters. The funeral is not attended by any clergy, or by Albert or Charlotte. The book ends with an intimation that Charlotte may die of a broken heart: "I shall say nothing of...Charlotte's grief. ... Charlotte's life was despaired of.". ุนููุงููุง: ยซุฑูุฌโูุง ูุฑุชุฑ ุฌูุงูยปุ ยซุบูโูุง ูุฑุชุฑ ุฌูุงูยปุ ยซุณโุฑฺฏโุฐุดโุชโ ูุฑุชโุฑ ุฌโูุงูโยปุ Espaรฑol / English. Calificaciรณn real: 2.5 Estrellas. Se cuenta la historia de Werther, un chico que ama la naturaleza y rechaza todo lo que es lรณgico o excesivamente razonado. El se muda a un lugar apartado y conoce a Carlota, una chica que estรก comprometida con otro hombre. Werther se enamora de ella y seguimos esta tragedia.. No se si leรญ este libro en mal momento, pero realmente me desesperรณ mucho. Demasiado drama. Estoy en medio de un reading slump y leer esto quizรก no fue la mejor soluciรณn. Werther hace de todo un drama y sobre exagera las cosas. Todos sus problemas los genera รฉl asรญ que no siento empatรญa ni compasiรณn por รฉl.. Aunque reconozco por que es un libro tan importante para los orรญgenes del romanticismo. Las descripciones de la naturaleza y los sentimientos son muy vividas y lo mejor del libro, es por eso que le otorgรณ las 3 estrellas.. Recomendado para quienes gusten de un libro romรกntico, lleno de frases bonitas para poner por ahรญ en Facebook.. _____________. Real rating : 2.5 stars. In this book we follow Werther, a young guy who loves nature and dislikes a very thing that has something to do with logic. He moves in to a place far away from home and he meets Carlota, a woman who is already engaged with another man. So Werther fall in love with her and then we have this tragedy.. Maybe I just read this book in the wrong time, because it is so annoying and frustrating. There's just too much drama! I'm in the middle of a reading slump so maybe reading this wasn't the best idea. Werther makes everything a big drama and overreacts to everything. He causes all of his troubles, so I didn't feel any empathy nor compasion.. I do have to recognize that it's a really important book for tor the origin of the romantic literary movement. The descriptions of nature and emotions are the best part of this book.. I recommend this to anyone who likes romantic drama, and also nice quotes to post on Facebook or something

701.	Der Prozess = The Trial, Franz Kafka. The Trial is a novel written by Franz Kafka between 1914 and 1915 and published posthumously in 1925.. One of his best-known works, it tells the story of a man arrested and prosecuted by a remote, inaccessible authority, with the nature of his crime revealed neither to him nor to the reader. Heavily influenced by Dostoyevsky's Crime and Punishment and The Brothers Karamazov, Kafka even went so far as to call Dostoyevsky a blood relative.. Like Kafka's other novels, The Trial was never completed, although it does include a chapter which brings the story to an end.. ูุญุงฺฉูู - ูุฑุงูุชุณ ฺฉุงูฺฉุง (ููููุฑุ ูุฑุฎุ 579.	L'etramgerโฌโฌ = The Outsider = The Stranger, Albert Camus. The Stranger is a 1942 novel by French author Albert Camus. Its theme and outlook are often cited as examples of Camus' philosophy of the absurd and existentialism.. Part 1: Meursault learns of the death of his mother, who has been living in a retirement home. At her funeral, he expresses none of the expected emotions of grief. When asked if he wishes to view the body, he declines and instead, smokes and drinks coffee in front of the coffin. Rather than expressing his feelings, he comments to the reader only about the aged attendees at the funeral. It takes place on an unbearably hot day. .... Part 2: Meursault is now incarcerated, and explains his arrest, time in prison, and forthcoming trial. His general detachment makes living in prison tolerable, especially after he gets used to the idea of being restricted and unable to have sex with Marie. He passes the time sleeping, or mentally listing the objects he owned in his apartment.. At the trial, the prosecuting attorney portrays Meursault's quietness and passivity as demonstrating guilt and a lack of remorse. The prosecutor tells the jury more about Meursault's inability or unwillingness to cry at his mother's funeral and the murder. He pushes Meursault to tell the truth, but the man resists. Later, on his own, Meursault tells the reader that he simply was never able to feel any remorse or personal emotions for any of his actions in life. The dramatic prosecutor denounces Meursault, claiming that he must be a soul-less monster, incapable of remorse, and thus deserves to die for his crime. .... ุนููุงู: ุจฺฏุงููุ ููุณูุฏู: Bulgarian review below/ะะตะฒััะพ ะฝะฐ ะฑัะปะณะฐััะบะธ ะต ะฟะพ-ะดะพะปั. โBut I fired four shots more into the inert body, on which they left no visible trace. And each successive shot was another loud, fateful rap on the door of my undoing.โ. You would want to loathe Camusโs protagonist and draw a line between yourself and him. Between you and this stranger among people, somewhat alien and detached even from his own thoughts. You will tell yourself that you are not like him. That you would cry at the funeral of your mother, you would fall in love with beautiful Marie and her tan, you would somehow help the neighborโs dog. Most of all, you wouldnโt kill a person, and in such an impassive manner.. We all know how our five senses deceive us. However, we frequently rely on that notorious sixth sense which is often more misleading than the rest of the bunch. And we trust our first impression. And itโs a sixth sense on amphetamines โ it throws itself forward with enthusiasm and you discern reality more clearly only after its impact has passed. The old translation joke is quite applicable to it โ. translation is like a woman โ if it is beautiful, it is not faithful; if it is faithful, it is most certainly not beautiful. . The jurymen are in a hurry to condemn this antichrist Meursault under the influence of their first manipulated impression. The prosecutor probably hypocritically believes he has fulfilled his public duty. Thank God we are not anything like the wicked Meursault, who, like that unfortunate monk who supposedly had written Codex Gigas, must have sold his soul to the Devil.. The philosophy of absurdism, represented fictionally in a concise manner by Albert Camus, is quite simple. Dangerously attractive as well. It gives a devious answer to the age-old question โWhatโs the meaning of life?โ Life doesnโt have a meaning. Perhaps. You can be truly free if you accept the absurdity of life. Nothing you do is of any importance. Perhaps.. โIn fact, everything is equal: writing โDemonsโ or having a coffeeโ. , Sartre writes in regard to the novel. Dostoevsky would probably have something to say to that. Iโm actually having a coffee while writing these lines, but that can hardly matter in any metaphysical plan. Perhaps.. Meursault is not a cold-blooded freak. Heโs not a sociopath. At times he experiences weak flashes of happiness or satisfaction. He also feels something that in such a person could be called compassion. He is simply indifferent to morality and follows his own inner sextant. He doesnโt want to pretend โ because that doesnโt matter anyway. He is a stranger in the eyes of others, precisely because he doesnโt want to be an ostentatious pretender. We all know that if we speak things that are pleasing to society, but we are doing entirely different stuff in secret, thatโs even praiseworthy. People have always loved some high quality mimicry.. โAnd I ended by believing it was a silly thing to try to force oneโs thoughts out of their natural groove.โ. Someone might think that the views of Meursault are a consequence of the stifling clerical life, which is something like Scylla and Charybdis, and the ordinary person is wedged between them. Far from it. Meursault seemingly does not seek any higher meaning to his existence, but as an exemplary representative of absurdism, he has completely accepted his position and doesnโt expect anything more from life. And you know, itโs very possible that heโs not quite mistaken.. โThe business of climbing a scaffold, leaving the world below, so to speak, gave something for a manโs imagination to get hold of. But, as it was, the machine dominated everything; they killed you discreetly, with a hint of shame and much efficiencyโฆ Imagination has never been one of my strong points.โ. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~. One of the best books of the author and probably the most well-known. I do not know where this popularity is due to but I can make the assumption that it is due to the fact that it is the most accessible of his great works, the one which the author's purpose is clearer, with that not meaning that it is a complex work, containing many more messages than are visible at first glance. But the basic message of human suffering and the possibility of correcting society through instinctive goodness and not by supposed revolutionary ideologies, by emotion and not by logic is clear, and the author gives it to the reader in the most staggering way.. As most people know, the story of this book starts with a murder, not something unusual, but because obviously we are not talking about a police story, the sequel is different. The killer and protagonist of the story believe that behind his act there are noble motives that can justify or, even more so, turn it into a heroic act that can become the starting point for a better life for many tortured people. Things, however, do not go as planned and because, in reality, he is not a bad person who could hurt someone without having any consciousness trouble, doubts start from the first moment and end in many days of reflection as he continues his life in most poor areas of St. Petersburg.. However, confronting this situation with the unhappy people living on the margins of survival in miserable homes, daily sacrificing their dignity to make a little money, finding a way out in alcohol, while the action of the most immoral people continues unabated while society in general shows the greatest indifference, the justification of his action becomes more powerful. Unable to overcome his selfishness he still believes that he simply got rid of a social parasite and thus offered something to people. This wall, however, is slowly breaking down as he associates with ordinary people who are truly sorry for this situation and by altruism sacrificing themselves without waiting for rewards. In front of these people who do not have the great theories and great ideas, that are simply driven by their Christian perceptions - which he so despises - this intellectual feels small and his complex analyzes and his determination to act accordingly to an unmistakable logical plan look like nothing more than manifestations of selfishness and arrogance. At the same time, the rope tightens around him and all that weight is growing, so the author takes us by the hand and leads us to ever more intense moments to the redemption finale.. Justified this book is considered one of the most important achievements in world literature which remains relevant today.. ฮฮฝฮฑ ฮฑฯฯ ฯฮฑ ฮบฮฑฮปฯฯฮตฯฮฑ ฮฒฮนฮฒฮปฮฏฮฑ ฯฮฟฯ ฯฯฮณฮณฯฮฑฯฮญฮฑ "One Hundred Years of Solitude" is one of my favorite books of all time. For me, it's a clear example of the undefined magical realism and certainly my favorite novel of the word genius Gabriel Garcรญa Mรกrquez. Nevertheless, I have to say that's not a book that everyone finds easy to read, I'll try to explain it. In 100 years of solitude, there isn't an objective, is not the kind of novels in which there is a clear protagonist that opposites to its antagonist and with clear goals to achieve. "One Hundred Years of Solitude" is a book about time, and this time is what holds all the novel; sometimes moving frantically and sometimes becoming slow and almost pasty. But the "magic words" of Marquez combined with his delicate and poetic form of telling a story builds in my opinion, one of the best masterpieces of our time. I encourage to read the novel to all of you who haven't ever read anything of this genius of writing and especially to those aspiring to become a great writer because in its pages you will find a well of literary wisdom.. Spanish version:. Cien aรฑos de Soledad es uno de mis libros favoritos de todos los tiempos. Para mi es un claro exponente del poco definido realismo-mรกgico y sin duda la novela que mรกs me gusta del mago de la palabra Gabriel Garcรญa Mรกrquez. Pese a ello tengo que decir que no es un libro que todo el mundo encuentra fรกcil de leer, me explicarรฉ. En 100 aรฑos de soledad no hay un objetivo, no es como el tipo de novelas a las que estamos acostumbrados en la que hay un protagonista claro, con antagonistas a los que oponerse o objetivos que alcanzar. 100 aรฑos de Soledad habla del tiempo, y รฉste tiempo es lo que hace avanzar la novela, a veces de forma vertiginosa y a veces de forma pausada y casi pastosa. Pero la "magia" de las palabras de Mรกrquez junto a su delicada y poรฉtica forma de los detalles de su narrativa hace que para mรญ sea una obra maestra. Os animo a todos aquellos que no hayรกis leรญdo nada de este genio de la escritura y sobre todo a aquellos aspirantes de escritor, en sus pรกginas encontrarรฉis un pozo de sabidurรญa narrativa.

My second bilingual review! I hope this came out well. The english review is first, then the Spanish./ยกMi segunda reseรฑa bilingรผe! Espero que esto saliรณ bien. La revisiรณn Inglรฉs es primero, luego el espaรฑol. (ยกMuchas gracias,. Florencia. ! - ". El mundo habrรก acabado de joderse el dรญa en que los hombres viajen en primera clase y la literatura en el vagรณn de carga.. "). ". I dare to think that it is this outsized reality, and not just its literary expression, that has deserved the attention of the Swedish Academy of Letters. A reality not of paper, but one that lives within us and determines each instant of our countless daily deaths, and that nourishes a source of insatiable creativity, full of sorrow and beauty, of which this roving and nostalgic Colombian is but one cipher more, singled out by fortune. Poets and beggars, musicians and prophets, warriors and scoundrels, all creatures of that unbridled reality, we have had to ask but little of imagination, for our crucial problem has been a lack of conventional means to render our lives believable. This, my friends, is the crux of our solitude.. " - La Soledad de America Latina (Nobel Lecture), December 8, 1982. Now let's all go to. Macondo. !. This book has capped off a year of me reading books that remind me of. Absalom, Absalom!. This was an amazing adventure into the life and death of family and a city. I was amazed, disgusted, amused, satisfied and not satisfied with this book. I obtained this book the week before its author died and waited a long time before deciding to read it--and only after I was sure I would like the genre of magical realism. Now because I have already been introduced to the genre from. Toni Morrison. , I was not taken by surprised by it here. It also helps that both Morrison and Garcia Marquez both were influenced by Will Faulkner. In any case, I want to focus more on the plot than the style.. This book is based on the history of Aracataca, Colombia and Latin America more broadly. The family that the book focuses on, called Buendรญa (literally good day in Spanish), are the representation of all that went right and wrong in Colombia's history up to that point and they brought to mind two other literary families: The Dead's of. Song of Solomon. and the titular family of. The Brothers Karamazov. . They are a very single-minded bunch that latches onto one passion or instinct and neglect all else, which leads them to "solitude," the overwhelming force that runs this novel. The family is so insular that its successive generations are named after its founding one throughout the century of this novel. Unlike in SOS, where the protagonist starts out with no past memories (and no past), which leads him to develop his past and almost seemingly travel back in time, The Buendรญas, only go forward enough before somehow losing their memories and simply repeating their past, to the point that no one remembers how the family came to be until it no longer matters.. The magic of this book lies in its narration. Because the change in time can be sudden, it was crucial for one uniform narrative style to persist among the entire novel and Garcรญa Mรกrquez does an amazing job. This also makes it easier to give a humorous tone to the novel. It is also a relief that GGM allowed his characters to really be themselves and he did not try to intervene on their behalves (which one could be tempted to do). I cannot say I liked or had a favorite character though maybe the town itself would qualify. GGM's Latin America suffers, in a way, from the same ailments as Faulkner's American South.. ". Amรฉrica latina no quiere ni tiene por quรฉ ser un alfil sin albedrรญo, ni tiene nada de quimรฉrico que sus designios de independencia y originalidad se conviertan en una aspiraciรณn occidental. No obstante, los progresos de la navegaciรณn que han reducido tantas distancias entre nuestras Amรฉricas y Europa, parecen haber aumentado en cambio nuestra distancia cultural. ยฟPor quรฉ la originalidad que se nos admite sin reservas en la literatura se nos niega con toda clase de suspicacias en nuestras tentativas tan difรญciles de cambio social? ยฟPor quรฉ pensar que la justicia social que los europeos de avanzada tratan de imponer en sus paรญses no puede ser tambiรฉn un objetivo latinoamericano con mรฉtodos distintos en condiciones diferentes? No: la violencia y el dolor desmesurados de nuestra historia son el resultado de injusticias seculares y amarguras sin cuento, y no una confabulaciรณn urdida a 3 mil leguas de nuestra casa. Pero muchos dirigentes y pensadores europeos lo han creรญdo, con el infantilismo de los abuelos que olvidaron las locuras fructรญferas de su juventud, como si no fuera posible otro destino que vivir a merced de los dos grandes dueรฑos del mundo. Este es, amigos, el tamaรฑo de nuestra soledad.. " - La Soledad de Amรฉrica Latina (Lectura Nobel). 8 Diciembre 1982. Este libro ha coronado un aรฑo de mi leyendo de libros que me recuerdan a. ยกAbsalรณn, Absalรณn!. Esta fue una aventura increรญble en la vida y la muerte de una familia y una ciudad. Me sentรญ sorprendido, disgustado, divertido, satisfecho e insatisfecho con este libro. Comprรฉ este libro una semana antes de que su autor falleciera y esperรฉ un largo tiempo antes de decidirme a leerlo - y sรณlo despuรฉs de haberme asegurado de que me gustarรญa el gรฉnero realismo mรกgico. Como ya me habรญa introducido al gรฉnero Toni Morrison, no me tomรณ por sorpresa. Tambiรฉn ayuda que tanto Morrison y Garcรญa Mรกrquez fueran influenciados por Will Faulkner. En cualquier caso, quiero centrarme mรกs en la trama que en el estilo.. Este libro se basa en la historia de Aracataca, Colombia y Amรฉrica Latina en general. La familia sobre la cual se centra el libro, que se llama Buendรญa, son la representaciรณn de todo lo que estuvo bien y mal en la historia de Colombia hasta ese momento y me trajeron a la mente (in your review in English, "to mind" appears twice) otras dos familias literarias: Los Muertos de. La Canciรณn de Salomรณn. y la familia titular de. Los Hermanos Karamรกzov. . Es un grupo muy resuelto que se fija en una sola pasiรณn o en un instinto y descuida todo lo demรกs, lo que conduce a "la soledad", la fuerza abrumadora que predomina en esta novela. La familia es tan estrecha que sus generaciones sucesivas se nombran acorde a la fundadora, a lo largo del siglo de esta novela. A diferencia de LCDS, donde el protagonista comienza sin ningรบn recuerdo (y sin pasado), lo cual lo lleva a desarrollar su pasado y casi a viajar atrรกs en el tiempo, los Buendรญa sรณlo continuan hacia adelante lo suficiente hasta que, de alguna manera, pierden sus recuerdos y simplemente repiten su pasado, al punto que nadie recuerda cรณmo la familia llegรณ a existir, hasta que ya no importa.. La magia de este libro radica en su narraciรณn. Debido a que el cambio en el tiempo puede ser repentino, era crucial que un estilo narrativo uniforme persistiera a lo largo de la novela y Garcรญa Mรกrquez hace un trabajo increรญble. Ello tambiรฉn hace que sea mรกs fรกcil para darle un tono de humor a la novela. Tambiรฉn es un alivio que GGM permitiera que sus personajes fueran realmente ellos mismos y que no intentara intervenir en su nombre (lo cual uno podrรญa sentirse tentado a hacer). No puedo decir que me haya gustado o que haya tenido un personaje favorito, aunque tal vez la ciudad en sรญ podrรญa serlo. La Amรฉrica Latina de GGM sufre, en cierto modo, de las mismas dolencias que el Sur de Estados Unidos de William Faulkner.. Puedo aรฑadir a esta reseรฑa del libro a medida que avanza, pero probablemente voy a escribir en sรกnscrito.

I knew this great writer through two of his other books,. Love in the Time of Cholera. and. Memories of My Melancholy Whores. that I really loved when I read them for the first time, I confess, though, that this book it was difficult for me. Not because I did not like it from its first page, I liked it very much because I found in it that beautiful writing that made the strongest impression on the books I mentioned before. What has made it difficult is the story that narrates which is seemingly simple, like a fairy tale, but it hides more in it. I loved it very much at first, I felt really enchanted, but then it was difficult to follow it, somewhere I found it confused, somewhere indifferent, and the multitude of events and of the leading characters it contained was enough to cause me fatigue. Above all, however, the fact that this story is essentially an allegory of the history of Latin America, with the events that marked this region of the planet, but also with the mentality of its inhabitants, their perceptions and obsessions, adds a particular weight for the reader, especially if he has an idea of this history.. Of course this difficulty does not mean that I was not aware of what I was reading or that it made me question the value of the book, quite the opposite, and this appreciation was increasing as I realized that the author wanted to say a lot and he did that through the pages he wrote. At some point, this becomes clear to the reader as historical references, with the coups, the interventions of foreign powers, political violence and everything that has plagued these peoples, as well as the social changes brought about by new technologies and new ideas, upsetting but also often reinforcing traditional perceptions. The village where history unfolds serves the writer to create a miniature of Latin America and this condensation of space is followed by the condensation of time, and so in not so many pages we have virtually everything. The interesting thing, however, is that the author does not give us everything ready and it is up to the reader to interpret what he reads but also to draw conclusions about their socio-political implications.. But I think, however, that I'm giving to much weight to the allegorical reading of the book and forget the human factor. There is of course the allegory and it is very intense, but there is also a very moving story of people who have faced the same problems from generation to generation, they were hurting, doing strange things or things quite common, were feeling, falling in love, being traumatized, looking with perplexity the new or become the agents of change and live their lives in their own way until the inevitable end. Men and women, typical cases of Latin American people, symbols but above all people who had the luck or the misfortune to live in a region of violence, ugliness but also of miracles.. For all of this, I finish the book with the feeling that I have read something really great, a great story that bends over the seemingly small and insignificant and gives a complete picture of human experience, both in Latin America and in the rest of the world.. ฮฯฯฯฮฝ ฯฮฟฮฝ ฯฯฮฟฯฮดฮฑฮฏฮฟ ฯฯฮณฮณฯฮฑฯฮญฮฑ ฯฮฟฮฝ ฮณฮฝฯฯฮนฯฮฑ ฮผฮญฯฮฑ ฮฑฯฯ ฮดฯฮฟ ฮฌฮปฮปฮฑ ฯฮฟฯ ฮฒฮนฮฒฮปฮฏฮฑ, ฯฮฟ.
